page.title: 02The Farms at Weaverthorpe
page.content: In this very rural area, farming is obviously the most important aspect. The whole area is{intensively farmed,} with very narrow hedges or none at all and apart from a few chalk pits, there is hardly any unploughed land, except from the steeper slopes in the dales which are grazed by sheep. When the land was enclosed in about 1803 under the leadership of{Sir} {Tatton Sykes}of Sledmere, the four outlying farms were built and each farmhouse and buildings surrounded by a shelter belt. These form the only woodland in the area. Most farms are now{owner-occupied.}Six are still {family farms,}worked by the farmer and one or two others full-time workers, often members of the family. Five farmhouses are in the village itself.
